reviewText:
This game is pretty much what it describes itself as: a Metroidvania + Point & Click Adventure game. If you have a problem with either of these genres, you might not enjoy the game but I love both so this is great for me.

For the P&C half you will be rubbing together items and trying to use them on characters/objects until you find a combination that works. This is pretty much a staple of the genre so I always find it odd when people complain about this mechanic. Most of the puzzles I've come across so far are pretty straight-forward, though. You should be able to guess what will work and what won't. The game does let you pick up useless items but I also found a dumpster that lets you throw out said useless items so if you've got stuff filling up your inventory, take a trip to the dumpster and if the game lets you throw it out, you won't need it. A pretty decent system, if you ask me.

The Metroidvania half is pretty much what you would expect: RPG leveling, places/items you can see but can't get to yet, backtracking, etc. You have a fireball attack (rapid fire is present so feel free to spam the attack button), a melee attack (automatically gets used when you try to shoot a fireball when you're too close to an enemy) and jumping to start off with but with upgrades as you progress.

Overall, it's a great game so far with few complaints and those complaints are very minor:
1 - The default gamepad controls were awkward and while you can remap the keyboard keys you can't remap the gamepad buttons so expect to open your gamepad software and make a profile for this game if you want to use your gamepad. (EDIT: Has been fixed in a patch.)
2 - The game uses the same button to open/use inventory as it does talking to people or inspecting objects so when you're trying to rub items on things you have to stand on the person/object to talk to/inspect them and then take a step to the side to try to use items on them. It's slightly awkward but not anything that breaks gameplay. You get used to it. (EDIT: Has been fixed in a patch.)
3 - Sometimes when I try to use items it will exit out of the item menu without trying to use it. Weird. Make sure to pay attention for the SFX for an item being used. If there's no SFX it canceled so you'll have to try again. (EDIT: This only happened for a few hours of my first run and then the controls started working fine after that. Not sure what the issue was.)
4 - I have come across a couple very minor bugs. I have a thread on the forums describing them. Nothing game-breaking. The dev is also on top of fixing them.

As I said though, those are all fairly minor issues. The game runs well, looks good, the characters and aesthetic are charming and it has a decent length, taking me about 8-9 hours to beat it the first time and about 15 hours to 100% complete it. If you like Metroidvanias and Point & Click Adventures then you should check this game out.

reviewText:
It’s a beautiful and cute game with great soundtrack and criminally low sales. You definitely should buy it, if you are into cute metroidvania-esque games with some quest elements.

You can call this game “cutelvania”: it’s cute and it’s metroidvania. You will explore a big magic school with paths blocked here and there, fight nicely designed but, sometimes, generic bosses and progress toward the end. The “True end” can feel a bit of anticlimactic, but I think that in it lies a twist and a lesson about how humanity evolved and became much stronger than SPOILERS.

Gameplay: it is your metroidvania: you explore the school; you find bosses; you defeat bosses; you gain abilities to progress through previously blocked paths. Some path requires you to solve puzzles just like old point and click adventures: here, have a bunch of items, now try to think how to combine them. Sadly, Belle’s inventory is limited, so you need to think what you will carry around and what will you leave near the portal. Jumping and moving are kinda slow and “floaty” which leads to frustration at some sections (mostly, with bosses). Hitboxes are big, unfair and make me sad.

Story: it’s cute and nice. No betrayals, no backstabbing, no evil plans — find ingredients for potions and enjoy colorful levels and enemies. I would surely play this game with my daughter (if I had one)

Characters: My teacher loves to unwind at nightclubs. Which is lovely.

reviewText:
<Disclaimer – This game was provided free for review purposes>

Mystik Belle is not your typical platformer. It manages to beautifully mash-up elements of Metroidvanian exploration and progression with logic based item puzzles typical of point and click adventure games. Throw in a handful of colourful characters, challenging boss fights and more raw oozing charm than you can shake a broomstick at, and the result is a fresh experience that remains enjoyable and satisfying all the way through.

In this game, you play as the Eponymous Belle McFae, a smart alecky, foul-mouthed witch in training who has just been framed for the destruction of the annual Walpurgisnact brew. After a thorough chewing out by her teachers, she is instructed to find three rare ingredients to make a new brew before sunrise. The initial story on offer in Mystik Belle is serviceable, and becomes more intricate as you progress, but what really fleshes out the world and makes you invested in the game, are the characters that Belle will encounter on her mission. The writing manages at all times to be entertaining  and full of charm – each character has their own unique personality and Belle’s interactions with them are definitely a high-point of the game. The attention to detail shown by the developer is fantastic, with many characters having unique dialogue lines and interactions for each item presented to them. Be it a hint on how to use it, or just a really meta nod to the player, these conversations between Belle and her friends were a real treat and while they added very little to the actual gameplay, still had me going back with each new item I found.

As stated, the gameplay is divided between platforming/combat and item puzzles. These puzzles should be familiar to anyone who has ever played a point and click adventure game – they consist of finding an item, and figuring out where to use it, or what other item to combine it with. Generally I found it enjoyable trying out different item combinations, as even when using the wrong item, Belle chimes in with a witty one-liner. The main problem I felt that this area of the gameplay suffered from was the inventory limit. Belle can only hold so many items before having to drop one, and towards the start of the game you are just collecting items with no idea what to do with them, additionally, the map only indicates where an item has been left, not what it is. This results in a lot of unnecessary backtracking and head scratching trying to remember where you left a specific item. I appreciate that metroidvanias often involve a lot of backtracking but this felt a little forced as though it was included simply to create the need to backtrack. Overall though, I felt that the adventure aspects on offer were solid, and were a lot of fun to experiment with.

As for combat, Belle begins simply with the ability to jump and shoot fireballs, but, in true Metroidvanian fashion, as you progress and level up, your arsenal of magical powers will expand to enhance both your combat abilities and means of traversal. The controls in Mystik Belle are certainly not as tight as I would have liked, resulting in a lot of cheap hits from foes. This is compounded by the sheer amount of enemy fire on screen, and the erratic patterns of flying enemies. Often I would lose a large chunk of health on the way to a boss and be forced to farm hearts for a few minutes. Thankfully, when enemies enter melee range, you can smack them with your broom, killing most small foes outright. I would have liked this melee attack to have greater application, such as deflecting enemy fire, this would have made combatting bosses much more enjoyable and enhance the combat system by forcing you to decide when to attack and when to defend. For better or worse, the combat remains very simplistic, with the unlockable charge shot being the weapon of choice for most encounters. Levelling up does improve your standard fireball attack considerably, but some involvement in the level up system would have been appreciated, as opposed to an automatic process.

Not too far into the story, Belle unlocks the dash ability, and this is easily the most painful part of the game. Dashing is performed by double tapping left or right and frequently activates by accident or more commonly, not at all. There is absolutely no need for dash to be assigned to the directional buttons. The triggers and bumpers on the gamepad aren’t even used for anything, and could have easily accommodated the dash ability. This seems like a strange oversight, and hopefully it can be patched by the developer, because not only is the dash unresponsive, it doesn’t feel as satisfying to perform as it should. This makes both getting around, and evading bosses harder and less enjoyable than they otherwise would be.

Despite one or two mechanical hiccups, Mystik Belle is still an exceptional game, and if there are two  areas where it really shines, it’s in its sound, and graphical design. Mystik Belle is straight up gorgeous and looks as though it was designed for the Sega Megadrive (or Genesis for you yanks), and this is by no means a criticism. The pixel art and animations within Mytik Belle are truly impressive and reminded me of the Shantae series throughout. It also proudly boasts some of the nicest shadow effects I’ve ever seen in a 16-bit game, which combined with the often spooky atmosphere of Hagmore Academy result in a visually stunning, well realised game world.  The soundtrack by Dan Rogers is another real treat. From the mysterious opening theme alone I could tell that this was going to be a good game. The frenetic, eerie chiptune tracks perfectly reflect the environs of the academy, and each is a joy to listen to. The tracks are diverse enough to not sound monotonous between areas, while retaining the same style throughout.

I greatly enjoyed the time I spent playing Mystik Belle, and would wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone looking for a good, old-school platformer game. For the work of a single man, Mystik Belle is a truly exceptional achievement, and I can’t wait to see what Andrew Bado, and LastDimension bring us next. The combat mechanics are a little rough around the edges, but the sense of exploration, progression and experimentation are as enjoyable and rewarding as many top shelf metroidvanias. If you want a game that’s oozing with style and charm from start to finish, look no further than Mystik Belle.

Pros:
+Gorgeous Pixel Graphics
+Stellar Soundtrack
+Terrific writing
+Solid adventure aspects

Cons:
-Combat is a little rough
-Dash mechanic

Score:8.5/10

reviewText:
I always say that Indie Games are like finding gems, you've got to get through the rough to find them first. Mystik Belle is a gem of an Indie game, deserving far more attention then it has gotten. From the art style, to the Metroidvania elements, everything in the game works well and cohesively. Playing Mystik Belle feels like catching up with an old friend, it just fits and feels right. Exploring a huge castle that slowly expands as you gain more spells and abilities. The game is fun, challenging, and does little to no hand holding whatsoever. This aspect is of particular of importance to note, given the games Point & Click features. Several moments in the game require you to combine or bring a correct item to a certain point in the game. The themes and music of Mystik Belle, are full of charm, and you can easily tell were a labor of love. Now that isn't to say that Mystik Belle is a perfect game. There are plenty of times in the game where you can feel overwhelmed and downright lost. The inventory system requires you to plan ahead and sometimes backtrack to complete a particular quest. However, the good vastly out weighs the bad in this game, long as you play smart. With 8 bosses, plenty of spells, and plenty to explore and find, Mystik Belle is going to give you plenty of bang for your buck. Throw on top of that some steam achievements, cards, controller support, and you've got a great game that deserves your attention.

reviewText:
Mystik Belle is a very enjoyable hybrid between metroidvania and inventory based adventure games, similar to the old Dizzy games or the more recent Spud's Quest made in the same style. Compared to its predecessors, there's a bit more action to help round out the metroidvania half of the experience, much to the game's benefit. Both halves are well made and then combined together into a game that's greater than the sum of its parts.

As a metroidvania, the controls are responsive and the boss fights challenging. Exploration is fun and rewarding, with lots of unique items to pick up. Map exploration requires puzzle solving in addition to acquiring new abilities, lending a fresh feeling to the traditional metroidvania formula.

As an adventure game, the puzzles are sensible and there are ample hints to keep you moving instead of getting stuck for too long. Many items have amusing effects when used in different locations, so even being stuck can be fun in its own right. Leveling up takes the sting out of backtracking or wandering around while stuck, rewarding you with increased health and the occasional attack upgrade for your effort.

Simply put, Mystik Belle is a fun and well designed game that's easy to recommend to metroidvania and adventure fans alike (and especially to fans of both). It's all the more impressive that it was made mostly by one person.

reviewText:
Mystik Belle is an appealing mix of Metroidvania and oldschool adventure that deserves much more attention than it's getting now.  The map design is simple but effective, the sprite artwork is beautiful and impressive, the dialogue is quirky, and it feels satisfying to play.

One element of the game that I particularly appreciated is that the adventure-esque puzzles are generally neither too obvious nor too cryptic.  At times, I got a little puzzled deciding where I needed to go next, but I never needed to resort to a walkthrough.  Everything makes sense.

I feel as if it could have used just a bit more refinement in certain areas, though.  My biggest qualm with the game might've been Belle's lack of defensive tactics.  She's not nearly small or agile enough character to avoid the barrage of attacks coming from all directions in certain situations, meaning that taking lots of damage is sometimes (seemingly) entirely unavoidable and creates some frustrating difficulty spikes, especially during later boss fights. Any sort of magic shield or dodging capabilities would have been greatly appreciated.  It also doesn't help that enemies randomly generate from the sides of the screen and sometimes hit you the moment you enter a new room.  In short, it doesn't always feel justified when you get hit.

A minor complaint that I have is that while the soundtrack is catchy and suits the mood quite well, I wish it had a bit more variety; it feels like one theme plays through the majority the game.  Item management is a hassle due to the very limited inventory space, leveling up feels like a chore until you max out, and I feel like it wouldn't have been difficult for both of those things to be set up more efficiently to keep the flow intact.

In the long run, these issues did no keep me from staying invested in the game for hours at a time until completion.  There are a lot of fun little details to it, and the whole concept is right up my alley.  For me, buying Mystik Belle was money well spent, and I could picture myself playing through it again sometime in the future.

Mystik Belle is an indie Metroidvania/Adventure game hybrid with excellent pixel presentation.  Like most adventure games, the game is very short once you understand what to do. Another issue is that the resolution is a bit small considering how nice and big the sprites all are. Despite these flaws, the dialogue, main character and setting are enjoyable enough and the game is tricky enough to keep you interested if you like the mechanics and futzing out solutions to things.  I definitely wouldn't recommend it to everyone, but there simply aren't any other games on steam quite like Mystik Belle, and if you can stomach a few nonsense puzzles most of what's here is worth it.

reviewText:
I just finished Mystik Belle and I have to say it was very well worth my time.

The obvious first: The graphics, animation and music are truly a treat. The same high quality from the screenshots is maintained throughout the game. The different areas are sufficiently unique and each has its own atmosphere. The soundtrack complements the game nicely.

The action is well-paced with superbly designed monsters and rewarding boss fights. The controls definitely need some getting used to and feel a bit sluggish at first, but soon enough everything falls into place.

Belle can level up, which increases hitpoints and firepower. When she dies, she is resurrected in the starting room with all items intact, but experience points reset to the beginning of the current level. So once the character levels up, that level remains fixed even after death.

Mystik Belle is sold as a Metroidvania with a point-and-click twist, the latter of which was a two edged sword for me. Belle has to find items which need to be used, either by themselves or combined with other items, to open new passages and advance the game. Since the developer wanted to reward the player for thinking about the items and paying attention to the conversations he decided to limit the inventory size, so you cannot keep all your stuff with you all the time. I kept all my belongings in one room so that I wouldn't have to go on a scavenger hunt as soon as I needed a specific item, but still I had to backtrack a lot. All in all these puzzles were not impossibly hard.

Mystik Belle was developed mainly by one person (except for the music), which I find an outstanding feat, and the game has an unbelievable level of polish for that. Metroidvania-purists may find the amount of skills to be learned somewhat limited though (one additional spell and two jump upgrades).

I finished the game in about eight hours. Visually, Mystik Belle has a lot to offer. The gameplay content I would describe as bite-sized, which I did not find particularly problematic since there are just so many things to see and explore.

There are two endings, the good one of which can be achieved by finding eight scrolls hidden throughout the map. Getting these will reward the player with an additional boss fight which, although not terribly challenging, was still exceptionally well done and gave the game a nice sense of closure.

I would definitely recommend the game.

Mystik Belle is a really charming metroidvania/adventure with a 16-bit aesthetics. It features beautiful pixel art visuals and a nice soundtrack and charming characters. The game is somewhat short once you know what to do and though there are undertones of a fleshed out setting, the NPCs aren't featured enough to create much of an attachment.

The description doesn't lie, though it has plenty of exploration and upgrades like metroidvanias, the bulk of progress is acheived by finding the right items and taking them to the right people and places, which takes a lot of guesswork, trial and error, like classic point and click games. It is made harder by giving you a limited inventory size, which means juggling items until you have the right ones to take to the right place. A helpful tip for players: leave items you don't know how to use in easy to reach rooms, as to avoid backtracking.

The metroidvania side of the gameplay is par for the course. You have a shooting attack that upgrades as you kill enemies, and you get more skills, either for attack or movement, as you progress. One bothersome detail is that the jumps at first are just barely high enough to reach the platforms above, so it takes a lot of pixel-perfect jumps until you are given skills to navigate more comfortably.

The genre mix is a novelty that can be as amusing as it becomes bothersome, and it doesn't revolutionize anything, but overall it's a charming game that can give you some hours of fun.

Pretty fun after you get used to the controls (just remember to map the Action and Menu buttons to two different keys if you don't like the default setup), and while the dash is kinda picky sometimes as to whether or not it'll activate everything else felt good, in my opinion.

Graphics are really excellent - pixel art that actually feels like something you'd see on the SNES or GBA but with some lighting effects to make them pop up. Music is also pretty catchy, especially in the later levels.

Couldn't find any glaring bugs in my playthrough, possibly due to the developer being so fast with the bug fixes. In fact, he's pretty active in the discussion area, and based on current topics it's likely that the game will only get better with time. As-is, though, it's still pretty solid.

One thing to note: This is a game that requires you to manage your inventory, talk to people constantly for clues and solve puzzles to progress. Playing it like your usual metroidvania will lead to frustrations, so if these are things you don't like then this is not the game for you. Mystik Bell may have a cute and artistic style that brings the game to life: but under the surface is a game that does not play to the genre's strengths, and really suffers for it. Silly restrictions of items put into place and no natural direction or player guiding litter a game with severe design problems left and right, which is a shame because it seems like the game engine itself is capable of bring out a great game. It's the kind of game that I hate: one where I can see the design elements really not playing well to what the game is trying to be, and me questioning every little decision that was made in order to get there. If you are a masochist at heart and don't mind putting up with wandering endless for no good reason, Mystik Bell may slightly have what you need, but honestly, it's a game that I would avoid, which is sad because there's a lot of wasted potential here.

+:
Art style hits all the right points, makes the world feel alive, and the different creatures stand out in several different ways.
Story elements seem reasonable, even if it's not the main focus.
-:
If you love backtracking, then ok. If you love ridiculously backtracking, then this game is for you. I don't. Not when it's completely unnecessary.
Very stupid decision to put an item limit on KEY ITEMS TO PROGRESS in place. This causes endless backtracking as you aren't given that many clues on exactly what you need for what portions of the map.
Why is the item usage and selections, as well as talking to a character, mapped to the same button? It makes absolutely no sense, resulting in repeated talking or item failure usages that could have easily been avoidable.
Level Design suffers with barely reachable jumps at times, as well as some silly enemy placement. Designers didn't understand the strengths of Metroidvania genre in regards to level design.
Don't ever allow enemies to spawn with you entering the room, right on top of you. Especially when the player can easily die to that. That's just frustration at its finest.
Due to all the above combined, you're left frustrated all over the place. You don't know what to do, and in particular, you're just confused.
Limited combat variety, but that could be due to not getting far enough.

Fair warning, I did get this from the creator as a gift for backing the Legend of Iya on Kickstarter, so bear that in mind.

This is an interesting title which rather takes the ♥♥♥♥ out of the Harry Potter Mythos while still being equal parts adventure game and equal parts metroidvania.  You play a tiny witch, Belle, who has been wrongly accused of ruining a brew and must metroidvania yourself around the school to try and make things right.  The dialogue here is quite amusing and there is a large amount of it.

The game can be down right hilarious with how nonchalant it is and how Belle herself realizes things other characters would take novels to realize and complains of how ridiculous it is.  When I say it is an adventure game though, take that to heart.  Inventory puzzles with occassional moon logic and all.  It gives you the same feeling of accomplishment for figuring out a puzzle, but can also leave your head scratching.  The metroidvania nature of it is quite basic, but still fun and addictive.

The game's music is quite catchy, though it needs more tracks as there are only a handful throughout.  The strongest point of argument I can make for Mystik Belle is the art.  The sprites in this game are beautiful, from the huge bosses to the unique look and feel off all the NPCs it is a true masterpiece of 2-d artwork.  The animations in the game, for some bosses or events, can be a bit limited or off, but overall I find it visually quite appealing.

The game will keep you busy for several hours, though admittedly some of that is back tracking.  Honestly, I do recommend it though.  It's much more engaging and fun than old school adventure games, but still has a lot of their charm in puzzle solving and questing.

Despite some claims of bugs or making the game unwinnable, I've never run into a situation like that.  Unlike Kings Quest, for example, death kicks you back to the beginning with all your items in tact, getting scolded by your head teachers and any place you can drop an item, you can get it back.  The game, for me, works quite well, though I do recommend a 360 controller to make the experience more enjoyable.

Give it a try.  For the price, it's a fun, decent lengthed, so far pretty unique, mix of Metroidvania and adventure games.

Let me preface this review with the following: I am not a person who usually plays nor likes metroidvania games. For me, they were just something that I never really felt compelled by and didn't have much fun with. I'm not a speedrunner, I seldom go for 100% completion in games, and to me these kinds of games really do encourage if not require you to have such tendencies to get the most out of the game.

With that said, I knew what I was going into before I started the game, having watched a few episodes of Let's Play episodes on Youtube. Eventually, I just found myself so charmed by the whole aesthetic and presentation of the game and decided that I didn't want to spoil myself further and just went to play it for myself.

I think what it was that sold me on this game was the odd mix of point-and-click gameplay with the standard metroidvania formula. The dialogue with NPC's and taking breaks in empty rooms to discover solutions to puzzles was a welcome departure from time to time when previously I was platforming and dodging enemies/projectiles. (Which to note, I didn't find myself having too much trouble with. Due to the rather generous HP/damage ratio, outside of some boss fights which required me 1-2 deaths to figure out their patterns, most of the game wasn't overly difficult, barring a few select rooms I could mention which were particularly brutal at first) It wasn't just because it provided a break from the other half of the gameplay though, but because I genuinely found myself taking an interest in the world and characters, which probably sounds odd considering the type of game it is. Sure, there isn't a huge amount of dialogue or world building to fill out an elaborate backstory, but there's just enough information given to the player that over my time of playing I found myself filling in the blanks and developing my own in-head cannon that was oddly both equally satisfying and interesting. Though, that may just be my nerdy tendencies.

Still, you're encouraged to indulge the NPC's and their dialogue, because while they give you interesting tidbits about the world, they also give you clues regarding the point-and-click aspects of the game. The game is pretty good about giving you clues about where to go and what to do, with me only having to consult the forums on one ocassion where I'd failed to have noticed something rather obvious.

It's worth mentioning that there are some bugs which I ran into but nothing ever rendered the game unplayable. (Falling out of bounds when you get wedged between a moving platform and spikes for example, but with that you can just exit and re-load and it will put you at the start of that screen) From what I've seen on the steam forums, the developer has done an excellent job fixing issues as they pop up, so I don't condemn it overly so for it.

With Mystik Belle, I feel that the developer was quite aware of the issues some players may have had with both point-and-click games -and- metroidvania games and made a game which brought the two of them together in a way that wouldn't alienate or scare off anyone not familiar with the genres. (NPCs offer the aforementioned helpful hints and dialogue, while bosses are all near the handy teleporters which offer quick access back to the room to re-try should you die) As someone who doesn't play either form of game much at all, I found myself progressing steadily through the game, with occasional hitches and challenges, and enjoying every minute of it from both the gameplay and charmingly silly characters. Casually playing through, it took me about 7 hours to reach the true end, and I can definitely see myself playing through again despite my usual tendencies of not doing so.

For a 13 dollar pricetag, while I admitedly had some hesitation at first, (Look, I'm stingy) It was definitely worth it. Even if you don't usually play metroidvania-esque games or find point and click logic unbearable, if you look at the trailer or watch some footage on youtube and find yourself charmed enough to be tempted, you'll probably find yourself having a good time.
